Tens of thousands of Iraqi security forces flooded the city, manning checkpoints, searching cars and inspecting neighborhoods.
It is a show of force meant to demonstrate that violence will no longer be tolerated, as NPR's Jamie Tarabay reports.
It began as most days in Baghdad begin.
Shopkeepers stacked boxes and chairs out in front of their stores.
Cafeteria workers squinting in the bright sun turned roasting chickens over in massive ovens and, of course, there was the traffic.
Law student Mohammed Fadel(ph) says the traffic is the only thing the security plan has delivered so far.
(Through translator) Until now the only result I've seen from the plan is the traffic jams, but we hope for better from the government.
It wasn't done right.
They announced it ahead of time and gave the terrorists in the trouble spots a chance to run away.
Interior Minister Jawad al-Bolani said it was important people knew about the plan in advance.
But newly appointed Defense Minister Abdul-Qader Mohammed Jassim contradicted that, saying the government should have gone ahead with the crackdown without telling anyone about it.
(Through translator) It was a mistake to spread the news about the military operation.
I thought it was wrong.
Anti-terrorist operations should be a surprise.
We shouldn't let the terrorists know so they can change their tactics and their locations.
Residents in some areas, like Abu Mea(ph), a Sunni neighborhood, knew they were on the list of trouble spots and many hid their weapons before the Iraqi police turned up.
Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki has made the Baghdad security plan the centerpiece of his strategy to bring stability to a country that's been wracked by lawlessness for more than three years.
Today he called on Iraq's people to support the plan.
(Through translator) Baghdad's security plan is a prelude for other plans for the rest of Iraq to face the challenges of terrorism.
We hope the people's voices will be heard and that everyone supports this plan by the government to keep the people of Baghdad safe.

Maliki assured Iraqis that unlike the last time Baghdad underwent a major security crackdown, this wouldn't be sectarian driven and that militias and insurgents, whether Sunni or Shiite, would all be targeted and subdued.
Aware that many Sunnis have no confidence in the largely Shiite police, he called on the security forces to carry out their duties respectfully.
(Through translator) We strongly urge them to respect human rights and not to attack the innocents, to keep their operations precise, because we don't want our citizens harmed.
We want them to be treated with dignity and respect.
